job_title: International Human Resources Officer in Washington, DC
pros:
I really enjoyed working for the Foundation and think it is full of great people doing admirable work.  The organization has some of the best benefits offerings I've ever seen, including paid parental leave, tuition assistance, and a generous 403(b) match.  It's a familial atmosphere that promotes events like 'EGPAF Trivia Night' and a companywide potluck Thanksgiving.  Even small things, like upgraded coffee pots and silverware in the kitchens, indicate that employees are valued.

My manager was extremely flexible with my schedule, which was great as I am a part-time student.  While there's always a lot of work to be done, you can generally do it on your own terms to achieve that elusive 'work/life balance.'

I would absolutely have stayed there longer if the job itself had been better aligned with my long-term professional goals.
cons: Like any midsize NGO, the budget is tight and growth opportunities (in terms of promotions, not professional development) are limited.  You have to be satisfied with your job and seek opportunities for professional growth (additional assignments, conferences, trainings, etc) to thrive.  That said, employees are promoted from within fairly regularly.

pros: EGPAF has a very passionate group of employees which makes it a great place to work because everyone loves the mission of the organization so much. Whether you have or have not worked in public health before, there is a ton to learn from this environment. The office is very laid back and has a "get your work done and you'll be fine" mentality, meaning if you perform well and work hard, no one is checking when you clock in or out; it's a very flexible environment with options for teleworking and flex schedules. From my own experience and watching other staff, if you do a great job with you role, you will be rewarded with a promotion and more money, and many managers are watching out for staff for additional opportunities so staff can grow their experience horizontally as well. Lastly, the benefits and time off perks are awesome.
cons: I did not personally have these challenges, but due to the size of the work environment in the US, it is difficult for some employees to grow past a certain level. Specifically, employees affected are those who are further along in their careers and the next step is management, but there is not always a management position open so that promotional growth is not always possible.

review_title: Wonderful mission but very top-heavy and poorly managed.
pros: I admit that the mission and work done abroad is wonderful, but the pros end there.
cons: DC office only (country offices not included in this review) - EGPAF prides itself at being the best in PMTCT, but this has led to hiring famous people/divas. I think this comes from Chip directly who has surrounded himself with his friends/cronies. The goal is to hire from the outside and not promote from within, which is silly if someone has highly rated performance.  Lower-level programming staff is worked to the bone with little opportunity for development or even thanks.  If you want a chance to learn and grow, do not work her.  If you want mindless tasks with no thanks and arrogance, this is the place with you.

review_title: Great Mission, Great Training Experience, Poor Long Term Prospects
pros: In a world where humanitarian assistance used to be king, Elisabeth Glaser (EGPAF), used to be tops.  The mission of the organization: to eradicate pediatric HIV/AIDS is incredibly noble.  Its execution is average.  Worldwide travel opportunities exist.  The ability to learn niche knowledge for public health and finance professionals is great.  For accountants and financiers in particular, grants and donor accounting will be the focus.  Travel to one of twelve overseas offices is possible.  Excellent pay and benefits.
cons: There is a culture of "keep quiet" and "don't challenge."  Generally, most folks should consider this organization as a springboard to better managed, more challenging humanitarian development jobs.  If you are new to this area, or need a job and receive an offer: take it.  Consider this move a temporary one, unless you enjoy working with the status quo.  High turnover (40% annually), says it all.

pros:
Everyone is very passionate about our mission--eliminating pediatric HIV/AIDS.
Most everyone works really hard.
Great international travel opportunities.
Good health and vacation/sick leave benefits (except maternity leave, which is absent).
Good telework flexibility and transit/parking support.
We're based in a great city (DC) with many partner organizations as our neighbors.
cons:
It used to feel like a we're-all-in-it-together organization, but changes in leadership over the past few years have made it very top-heavy, with VPs with unclear job descriptions and perks that are not passed down to non-leadership staff, such as business-class travel (domestic and international). Under our former CEO, everybody flew coach, which said a lot about her commitment to her staff.

The organization is short-sighted in that they seem to be chasing whatever is trendy rather than building our own brand and technical expertise. In less than 3 years, our communications unit has created 2 new major 'buzz term" campaigns, rather than just trying to make our existing name more well known outside of the HIV community. Field and programmatic staff never have an opportunity to weigh in on the slogans, especially on whether or not they'll be culturally acceptable in our supported countries (15). Junk is created to go with them (water bottles, t-shirts, totes), then when the slogans are inevitably scrapped, money is just wasted.

A willingness to broaden our scope only comes as a result of Gates, USAID or CDC showing interest in a particular area and being willing to fund it. There was zero interest from leadership in maternal-child health issues besides PMTCT (family planning, safe motherhood, gender-based violence, etc...) until CDC began putting out funding opportunities. When other organizations win because they're already doing that work, better than we could at this stage, we scramble and beg for scraps as a sub-partner. We could lead in these areas and be a real MCH-focused organization if our leadership would have the courage and creativity to go after private, non-traditional donors to fund us to be innovative, rather than chasing the priorities of USAID, CDC, or Global Fund. 

As an organization supposedly focused on mothers and families, it's an embarrassment that this organization does not provide maternity or paternity leave. Salaries are okay, if on the lower-end of the NGO scale, but the lack of maternity leave is a real shame, and just a slap in the face.

pros: Terrific mission and niche as the global advocate to end AIDS in children. review_title: Overall, a very rewarding place to work
pros: I have worked at the Foundation for just over five years and am very happy that I took this job.  The Foundation offers opportunities for upward movement and most people in supervisory roles are legitimately concerned about, and try to foster, people's well-being.  One very good aspect of working for the Foundation that I have definitely not experienced in the other places in which I have worked is that many, many people, at all levels of the organization, have a "seat at the table."  In my previous jobs, only senior management were given the opportunity to make significant decisions and most personnel were not consulted in those decisions;  Not so at the Foundation - Here, I love that I have been given the opportunity to sit in meetings, participate in calls, etc. that have helped shape policy and overall direction even though I am in the relative early stages of my overall career.
cons: There is sometimes a "do as I say and not as I do" attitude that emanates from selected executives.  It would be nice to work in a place no one (whether an upper-level executive, a mid-level manager, or a brand-new, fresh out of college hire) is given special exceptions.  But if you're reading this and know of a place where that happens, please be sure to let me know about it because I doubt that that place exists.

review_title: Wonderful Organization with great opportunity and growth!
job_title: Corporate Services Officer in Washington, DC
pros:
I worked at the Foundation for almost 6 years, and had an incredible experience from start to finish! I was promoted, through hard work and dedication, several times during my tenure. It seems that several of the past reviews indicate that there wasn't growth opportunity, but this simply isn't true; however, growth is something that is earned, not just given away to any who believe they deserve it. 

Senior leadership at the Foundation is incredibly accessible to all ranks of employees; if an employee had concerns or wanted to speak with someone on the senior leadership team, they would make time and take the employees thoughts very seriously. 

The Foundation is quite forward thinking, recognizing the need to evolve and change as the needs of the organization change. Our structure evolved in my time at the Foundation, and created opportunity for staff to grow. 

Employee appreciation and recognition is great, with periodic Foundation events, giveaways and happy hours. It was nice to be able to get together with Foundation staff and get to know them!

While no one particularly loves doing annual reviews, the Foundation provides 360 degree review opportunities, so you are given the chance to provide confidential feedback on your manager. I found this to be helpful in giving constructive feedback without having to have a face-to-face conversation with my manager.

Overall, the Foundation was such a wonderful, mission-driven organization to work for, and I feel so lucky to have had the chance to learn and grow with them! Anyone considering working at the Foundation would be lucky to work there!
cons: The only con to the Foundation is that some departments are able to travel more than others, mainly due to budget constraints and priorities, which can be a bit of a disappointment to staff who don't get to travel as often. But this is such a small complaint compared to the organization as a whole.
